questions.explanation: A motorcycle is a full-size vehicle with the same privileges as any other vehicle on the roadway. You should allow a motorcyclist a full lane width. Although it may seem as though there is enough room in the traffic lane for a larger vehicle and a motorcycle, remember that the motorcycle needs room to maneuver safely.

questions.question: When parking uphill next to a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Keep the rear tires against the curb.
questions.answerB: Keep the front tires straight ahead.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel away from the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn your steering wheel toward the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking facing uphill on a street that has a curb, set your parking brake and turn your steering wheel away from the curb. This way, if your vehicle starts to roll, it will roll into the curb.

questions.question: When approaching an accident scene, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention on your driving.
questions.answerB: Keep moving.
questions.answerC: Stop if you are involved or if emergency help has not yet arrived.
questions.explanation: Do not stop at an accident scene unless you are involved or emergency help has not yet arrived. Keep your attention on your driving and keep moving, watching for people who might be on or near the road. Never drive to the scene of an accident, fire, or other disaster just to look.

questions.question: You may continue carefully through an intersection with a yellow light if:
questions.answerA: There is an emergency vehicle crossing your lane.
questions.answerB: There are pedestrians crossing.
questions.answerC: You are turning right.
questions.answerD: You are already within the intersection when the light changes to yellow.
questions.explanation: If a steady yellow light appears when you are already within an intersection, you should continue through the intersection carefully.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn.
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: A red flashing traffic light has the same meaning as a:
questions.answerA: Solid red light.
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Yield sign.
questions.explanation: A red flashing traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. When approaching a red flashing signal, come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so. A stop sign may sometimes also be posted where this signal is located.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: School ahead.
questions.answerB: School crossing.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerD: Construction workers on or near the roadway.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that there may be pedestrians crossing the road ahead.

questions.question: You may not cross a single broken white or yellow line:
questions.answerA: When doing so would interfere with traffic.
questions.answerB: When turning left into a driveway.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is disabled.
questions.answerD: When passing to the right on a one-way street.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single broken line to pass or change lanes as long as you can do so safely and without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: You are driving on a multilane highway and wish to change lanes. You must signal your intentions:
questions.answerA: Immediately before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Only during the lane change.
questions.answerC: At least 50 feet before beginning to change lanes.
questions.answerD: At least 100 feet before beginning to change lanes.
questions.explanation: Signals must be given for at least 100 feet before changing lanes or turning. This is approximately the length of five cars. It is advisable to signal for a greater distance when driving at higher speeds.

questions.question: A person walking with a white cane or guide dog is likely to be:
questions.answerA: A deaf person.
questions.answerB: A person involved with a traffic study.
questions.answerC: A blind person.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian when the pedestrian is a blind person who is using a white cane or guide dog.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: When you want to make a right turn, your car must be:
questions.answerA: Near the center of the street.
questions.answerB: Close to the left side of the street.
questions.answerC: Close to the right side of the street.
questions.answerD: Past the center of the intersection when you begin to turn.
questions.explanation: As you prepare to make a right turn, you should get as far to the right side of the road as possible. Do not cut across lanes of traffic to perform any turn.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about driving on a wet roadway?
questions.answerA: As you drive faster, your tires become less effective.
questions.answerB: Water does not affect cars with good tires.
questions.answerC: Deep water is less dangerous than shallow water.
questions.answerD: As you decrease your speed, the roadway becomes more slippery.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive on a wet roadway, the less effective your tires will be at wiping the water from the road. If your speed becomes excessive enough, your tires will lose their grip on the road entirely and you will begin to hydroplane (that is, to slide down the road on a film of water).

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Yield.
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: Keep right.
questions.explanation: Traffic signs with three sides of equal length warn drivers to slow down when approaching an intersection and to be prepared to come to a complete stop to yield to other drivers or pedestrians. Drivers may proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel at the speed indicated.
questions.answerB: The maximum legal speed on the roadway is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed.
questions.explanation: This is a speed limit sign. It indicates the maximum legal speed that you may drive on the road where it is posted. At times of rain, snow, ice, or other less-than-ideal conditions, you may have to drive more slowly than the posted limit.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerA: Allergy medicine
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: If not otherwise prohibited by a sign, a driver stopped at a solid red traffic light may turn left:
questions.answerA: Onto any street if there are no other vehicles or pedestrians present at the intersection.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: From a two-way street onto a one-way street.
questions.answerD: From a one-way street onto another one-way street.
questions.explanation: Unless a sign prohibits such movement, you may turn left on a red light from a one-way street onto a one-way street where traffic is moving to the left. Before turning, you must come to a complete stop and be sure there are no vehicles or pedestrians in your path.

questions.question: A copy of your vehicle inspection certificate:
questions.answerA: Should be kept in the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should be filed with your income tax return.
questions.answerC: Should be kept in a safe place in your home.
questions.answerD: Will be sent to you by the County Department of Finance.
questions.explanation: All motor vehicles operated on public highways must have an official Periodic Motor Vehicle Inspection (PMVI) at least once a year. Upon approval, a sticker is affixed to the vehicle and two copies of the inspection certificate are issued to you. The certificate must remain in the vehicle.

questions.question: A red traffic signal light means that you must:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop line.
questions.answerB: Stop before entering any crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection.
questions.explanation: A red traffic light means that you must stop before entering the intersection. You must at any stop line and before entering any crosswalk.

questions.question: Which of the following influence(s) the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerA: The amount of food in the stomach
questions.answerB: The body weight of an individual
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. Eating before or while you drink helps slow the absorption of alcohol somewhat, but it cannot prevent intoxication or impairment if you have too much to drink.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: Traffic signs and pavement markings:
questions.answerA: Must always be obeyed.
questions.answerB: Are merely suggestions.
questions.answerC: Must be followed only when there is other traffic.
questions.answerD: Must be followed only when a police officer is present.
questions.explanation: Traffic flow is controlled by pavement markings, traffic islands, signals, and signs. These devices inform drivers of conditions on the roadway and help guide drivers safely to their destinations. You must always obey traffic signs, signals, and pavement markings.

questions.question: What is a "No zone?"
questions.answerA: A designated no passing zone
questions.answerB: A one-way traffic area
questions.answerC: The blind spot of a large vehicle
questions.answerD: An area designated for motor vehicles
questions.explanation: "No zones" are the large blind spots around trucks and other large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in "No zones."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians ahead.
questions.answerB: End of construction zone.
questions.answerC: School crossing ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a flagger ahead controlling traffic in a construction area.

questions.question: Before entering a roundabout, you must slow down and yield to:
questions.answerA: Vehicles in the roundabout.
questions.answerB: Bicyclists in the roundabout.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians in the roundabout.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and vehicles that are already in the roundabout.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Left turn yield on green.
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When towing a loaded trailer that weighs more than one-half of the towing vehicle's weight, or is 3,000 pounds or more, the trailer must be equipped with:
questions.answerA: Brakes.
questions.answerB: Breakaway protection.
questions.answerC: Hub caps.
questions.explanation: If your loaded trailer weighs more than half the weight of the towing vehicle, or is 3,000 pounds or more, the trailer must be equipped with brakes and breakaway protection.

questions.question: Traffic regulations require drivers to display a turn signal for at least ____ before making a turn or lane change.
questions.answerA: 50 feet
questions.answerB: 75 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.explanation: Turn signals must be displayed for at least 100 feet before changing lanes or turning. It is advisable to signal for a greater distance when driving at increased speeds.

questions.question: The most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of being injured or killed in a traffic crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear your seat belt.
questions.answerB: Limit your driving to weekdays.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane on multilane highways.
questions.answerD: Limit your driving to hours between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m.
questions.explanation: Wearing your seat belt is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of death or injury while driving.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This signs indicate that U-turns are prohibited in the location where it is posted.

questions.question: What is the meaning of this sign?
questions.answerA: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a red light.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal ahead is broken.
questions.answerC: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a green light.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal at the intersection ahead.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You need to use extra caution when driving near a pedestrian using a white cane because:
questions.answerA: He or she is deaf.
questions.answerB: He or she is a police officer.
questions.answerC: He or she is blind.
questions.answerD: He or she has poor balance.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: When passing other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn at least three times.
questions.answerC: Re-enter your lane within 10 feet of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing another vehicle, check your mirrors and blind spots. Before changing lanes, activate the appropriate turn signal. Re-enter the lane when you can see the front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: To avoid being in a truck or bus driver’s blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Never pass them.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving alongside them and avoid tailgating.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights at them.
questions.explanation: Because a large vehicle, such as a truck or bus, has large blind spots to its sides and rear, avoid driving alongside such a vehicle and do not tailgate one.

questions.question: When approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and/or flashing lights, a driver must immediately:
questions.answerA: Pull to the right and stop.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right and slow down.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and turn on their vehicle's four-way flashers.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the emergency vehicle pass.
questions.explanation: When you are approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its lights, sirens, and/or other warning devices, you must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop.

questions.question: If you need to stop quickly and your vehicle is not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Hold down the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Firmly pump your brakes.
questions.answerC: Lightly tap the brakes.
questions.explanation: Pumping the brakes is generally the best way to stop a car in an emergency. The car will stop quickly and you will also be able to continue steering.

questions.question: A speed limit is:
questions.answerA: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under dangerous conditions.
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.answerC: The suggested speed to travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit is the maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed, but it is illegal to drive any faster. You must drive more slowly where signs or signs indicate a school zone or work zone speed limit. If conditions such as road construction or bad weather make the posted speed unsafe, drive under the speed limit.

questions.question: If two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time:
questions.answerA: The largest vehicle has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car on the left shall yield to the car on the right.
questions.answerD: The car on the right shall yield to the car on the left.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive at the same time to an uncontrolled intersection, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right. The driver on the left may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Animal crossing.
questions.answerB: School crossing.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: Five-sided signs indicate there is a school nearby and drivers should be alert to children and pedestrians in or near the road. This sign indicates a school crossing. Drivers must obey any instructions given by a crossing guard.

questions.question: A slow-moving vehicle emblem is:
questions.answerA: A rectangular red sign.
questions.answerB: A circular green sign.
questions.answerC: A diamond-shaped yellow sign.
questions.explanation: The slow-moving vehicle symbol is a reflective orange triangle. Expect vehicles using this emblem to be driving at speeds of 25 mph or slower.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: You may cross double solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass a slow-moving truck.
questions.answerB: To turn into a driveway.
questions.answerC: To pass another car.
questions.explanation: Double solid lines indicate that you may not pass or change lanes. You cannot cross the lines unless it is to turn left to enter or exit a highway, to turn into or from a driveway, or to make a U-turn (where permitted).

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: Two-way left turn.
questions.answerC: Minimum speed limit.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. Wherever this regulation sign is posted, U-turns are not permitted.

questions.question: Follow the vehicle ahead of you at a distance of at least:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: 100 feet.
questions.explanation: Vehicles being struck from behind is a common occurrence on the roadways. To avoid this hazard, leave a minimum two-second interval of space between you and the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: You are driving on the roadway and hear a siren behind you. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop where you are.
questions.answerB: Pull over to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up to get out of the way.
questions.explanation: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an emergency vehicle coming from behind your vehicle, you must create a clear path for the emergency vehicle and stop. Reduce your speed and safely pull over to the side of the road. If the emergency vehicle is directly behind your vehicle when you are in heavy traffic, keep moving slowly until you can get out of its way.

questions.question: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get out of the car and go for help.
questions.answerB: Lay down in your car and go to sleep.
questions.answerC: Walk into the road and get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerD: Stay in the car, as you are most likely to be found when you stay in your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is stay in your car and wait for help. You are most likely to be found if you don't leave your vehicle. Additionally, it may be unsafe to walk around outside in a snowstorm.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerA: A bad driving habit.
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is merging traffic entering from the right.

questions.question: As alcohol builds up in your blood, it:
questions.answerA: Slows down your reactions.
questions.answerB: Makes you feel less confident.
questions.answerC: Begins to metabolize itself more quickly.
questions.answerD: Decreases the number of driving errors.
questions.explanation: As alcohol builds up in your system, it will slow your reactions, make you feel more confident, and cause you to make more errors.

questions.question: Newer vehicles have equipment warning lamps installed on the instrument panel. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: All lamps should be illuminated when the ignition switch is first turned on before the engine is started.
questions.answerB: No lamps should illuminate until the engine is running.
questions.answerC: The lamps should never illuminate unless there is a malfunction.
questions.answerD: The lamps will only illuminate if the headlights are turned on.
questions.explanation: Equipment warning lamps on a vehicle instrument panel should all be illuminated when the ignition switch is turned on. A warning lamp that is not illuminated when the ignition switch is turned on indicates that the lamp is not functioning.

questions.question: If you see this sign above your lane, you:
questions.answerA: May not exit the freeway.
questions.answerB: May either continue through the interchange or exit the freeway from your current lane.
questions.answerC: May stay in your lane and continue through the interchange.
questions.answerD: Must exit the freeway, if you stay in your current lane.
questions.explanation: If a yellow panel with the message "Exit only" is on a highway sign, the lane below the sign will not continue through the interchange. Instead, the lane will go off of the roadway to form a ramp. If you are in a lane directly under an "Exit only" sign, you may change lanes to move through the interchange or you must exit the highway.

questions.question: The most effective safety restraints in a traffic crash are:
questions.answerA: Only a lap and shoulder belt.
questions.answerB: Only an airbag.
questions.answerC: Both a lap/shoulder belt and an airbag.
questions.explanation: Safety belts can double your chance of surviving a crash and more than double your chance of avoiding serious injury. Airbags, when used properly with safety belts, provide additional protection in a front-end crash. You should wear both shoulder and lap belts.

questions.question: You come to an intersection that is blocked by other traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Go slowly until the traffic ahead moves.
questions.answerB: Get as close as possible to the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Stay out of the intersection until you can pass through.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to make the cars move up.
questions.explanation: You cannot enter an intersection if traffic is backed up on the other side and you cannot get completely through the intersection. Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: You must yield to other drivers:
questions.answerA: When entering a street from a garage or alley.
questions.answerB: When they are on a road to your left and you have reached an unmarked intersection at the same time.
questions.answerC: When your traffic signal is a green arrow.
questions.explanation: You must yield to other drivers when entering a street from an alley, driveway, or garage. You must also yield to pedestrians who are on an intersecting sidewalk.

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: If one of your tires blows out as you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake hard immediately.
questions.answerB: Try to steer straight while gradually slowing by removing your foot from the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Maintain your current speed and steer straight.
questions.answerD: Swerve back and forth to alert traffic behind you.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the car headed straight down the road. Ease your foot off the gas pedal and do not apply the brakes until you have complete control. When the car is under control, brake gently and pull off the road at the nearest safe location.

questions.question: Larger vehicles have:
questions.answerA: Larger blind spots.
questions.answerB: Smaller blind spots.
questions.answerC: No blind spots.
questions.answerD: The same blind spots as smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: The larger the vehicle, the larger the blind spots. Large trucks and SUVs have spots close to their rears that cannot be seen in their side or rearview mirrors.

questions.question: If your car breaks down on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in your car and wait for help.
questions.answerB: Use your four-way flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn at passing motorists.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights at oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the highway, you should signal before carefully exiting the roadway and turning on your hazard flashers. Get as far off the road as possible and park in a location where other drivers can easily see you. Lift your hood to let other drivers know your vehicle is disabled.

questions.question: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you:
questions.answerA: May still turn, but you must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: May no longer turn and must proceed straight.
questions.answerC: Still have the right-of-way to turn.
questions.answerD: No longer have to turn in the direction that the arrow indicated.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you may still turn in the direction that the arrow was pointing but you must first yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You are driving up a hill and are approaching a heavy truck from the rear. You should know that:
questions.answerA: The truck may be traveling at a speed slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: You may not be able to safely pass the truck.
questions.answerC: You may not be able to legally pass the truck.
questions.explanation: Drivers must be aware that large vehicles often travel at a speed slower than the posted speed limit, especially when driving on an incline, and should use caution when approaching a large vehicle from the rear. When on a hill with limited visibility, it is unlawful to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: A speed limit sign is posted on a freeway exit ramp. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow to this speed before entering the deceleration lane.
questions.answerB: Regard the posted limit as only a suggestion.
questions.answerC: Never drive slower than the posted speed on the exit ramp.
questions.answerD: Slow to the posted speed once entering the exit ramp.
questions.explanation: When exiting the freeway, maintain your speed until you are completely into the exit ramp, then slow down smoothly. Treat a posted speed limit sign on a freeway exit ramp as you would any other speed limit sign.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A green arrow:
questions.answerA: Is used only on one-way streets.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic must turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: Means that you may proceed, but only if the green arrow is accompanied by a circular green light.
questions.answerD: Points the way to an airport.
questions.explanation: A green arrow has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic in the indicated lane must turn in the direction shown by the arrow.

questions.question: You are late to work and in a hurry. Before you back into the street, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn.
questions.answerB: Check for children and other objects around your car.
questions.answerC: Rev your engine so that animals will get out of the way.
questions.answerD: Check for traffic before getting into your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Backing is a dangerous maneuver due to the restricted visibility and should be done with great caution. Exercise extraordinary caution when backing up in residential areas. Children often play behind and between parked vehicles.

questions.question: The best way to avoid hydroplaning is to:
questions.answerA: Keep your tires properly maintained.
questions.answerB: Slow down when roads are wet or slushy.
questions.answerC: Watch out for standing water or puddles.
questions.explanation: When roads are wet, cars take a longer distance to stop and may skid on quick turns. Do not use cruise control when driving under wet or icy conditions. Reduce your speed and drive with caution.

questions.question: If you drink alcohol socially, what helps ensure safe driving?
questions.answerA: Drink coffee before driving.
questions.answerB: Ride home with a friend who has not been drinking.
questions.answerC: Take a cold shower before driving.
questions.answerD: Stop drinking one half hour before driving.
questions.explanation: One strategy to avoid driving while impaired or intoxicated is to arrange for a ride home with a friend who does not drink. Drinking coffee or taking a cold shower cannot reduce your blood alcohol content or reduce the effects of alcohol. On average, it takes about an hour for the body to eliminate the alcohol from a single drink.

questions.question: A good rule to remember for passing is:
questions.answerA: Pass on the right whenever possible.
questions.answerB: Drive with the flow of traffic and pass only as needed.
questions.answerC: Try to get to the front of any slow-moving traffic so that you can see better.
questions.answerD: Always flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your intentions.
questions.explanation: Each time you pass another vehicle, there is an increased chance for a collision. If you are moving faster than surrounding traffic, you will have to continue passing others. Drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit, and pass only as needed.

questions.question: If you are involved in an accident and the accident scene is not readily visible to oncoming traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Have someone warn approaching traffic.
questions.answerB: Let oncoming traffic watch out for themselves.
questions.answerC: Let the police handle everything.
questions.answerD: Assume other drivers will have heard the crash.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident and the accident scene is not readily visible to oncoming traffic, you should warn oncoming traffic. Have someone warn approaching drivers to prevent further damage. Keep a flashlight and flares in your vehicle for emergency use.

questions.question: Compared to driving during the day, driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Less dangerous.
questions.answerB: No more or less dangerous.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day for several reasons. It is harder to see in the dark, you may be temporarily blinded by the glare from other vehicles' lights, and there are likely to be more drivers on the road who are tired or under the influence.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for bicycles.
questions.answerB: Bicycles not allowed.
questions.answerC: Bicycle repair shop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign provides advance warning that bicycles may be present.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and another person is injured. You should:
questions.answerA: Moved the injured away from the scene immediately.
questions.answerB: Always leave the injured where they are.
questions.answerC: Not move the injured unnecessarily. Keep the injured warm and administer first aid.
questions.explanation: After an accident, do not move the injured unnecessarily. Unskilled handling can make serious injuries out of minor ones. Keep the injured warm until skilled help arrives. If there is severe bleeding, attempt to stop the flow of blood with direct pressure.

questions.question: Is it legal cross a double solid yellow centerline to pass?
questions.answerA: Yes.
questions.answerB: No.
questions.answerC: If there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: If the vehicle ahead of you is driving under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Two solid yellow lines down the center of a two-way road mean that neither lane of traffic may cross the lines, unless they are turning off of the roadway. A driver can cross double yellow lines when turning into or out of a driveway or entrance to a business. No passing is allowed over a solid yellow line.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerA: An intersection.
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and your vehicle is blocking traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible.
questions.answerB: Not move your vehicle under any circumstances.
questions.answerC: Wait until the police arrive before moving your vehicle.
questions.explanation: After a minor collision, move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible. Do not leave the scene of an accident without identifying yourself and rendering assistance.

questions.question: When driving on slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Use alternate routes.
questions.answerB: Drive as you would on dry roads.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: On slippery roads, you should increase your following distance. It may take more time to stop your vehicle than it would under normal conditions.

questions.question: When driving on major highways:
questions.answerA: Stay alert.
questions.answerB: Keep your eyes moving.
questions.answerC: Be ready to react to road hazards.
questions.explanation: It is important to stay alert on highways and be ready to react to unexpected hazards. To avoid "highway hypnosis," you should avoid looking at any one thing for more than a few seconds.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Winding road.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: You must stop at an intersection when you see a:
questions.answerA: Flashing red light.
questions.answerB: Steady yellow light.
questions.answerC: Yellow arrow.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. At an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a complete stop, look both ways, and proceed only after the intersection is clear.

questions.question: Stress can affect your driving by:
questions.answerA: Lowing your ability to focus on driving.
questions.answerB: Decreasing your chances of an accident.
questions.answerC: Causing you to fall asleep at the wheel.
questions.answerD: Making you more aware of others around you.
questions.explanation: Emotions can have a great effect on your driving ability. You may not be able to drive well if you are overly worried, excited, afraid, angry, or sad. Stress can lessen your concentration on the task of driving. It is better to wait to drive than to risk driving while you are emotionally unstable.

questions.question: If someone has consumed alcoholic drinks, what will help the person overcome the influence of those drinks?
questions.answerA: Tomato juice and lime
questions.answerB: Hot coffee
questions.answerC: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time will allow a person to overcome the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When towing a trailer load, ensure that the trailer’s load is properly balanced. About ____ of the total trailer weight should be on the vehicle’s trailer hitch.
questions.answerA: Five percent
questions.answerB: 10 to 15 percent
questions.answerC: 15 to 20 percent
questions.explanation: About 10 to 15 percent of a trailer's weight should be on the towing vehicle’s trailer hitch. If the weight is poorly distributed, the driver will have trouble controlling the vehicle or trailer.

questions.question: You cannot pass safely on a two-way, two-lane street unless:
questions.answerA: You are able to clearly see the road ahead.
questions.answerB: You can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass.
questions.explanation: You cannot pass safely when driving on a two-way, two-lane street unless you can clearly see the road ahead, you can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic, and your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass. Do not pass where it is illegal and unsafe to do so.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
questions.explanation: On narrow roads, you must allow vehicles traveling in the opposite direction at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road. Both vehicles must have adequate space in order for the drivers to safely pass one another.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing yellow light. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for the light to change.
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn because the intersection is closed.
questions.answerC: Drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Prepare to stop; the light is about to turn red.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should proceed through the intersection slowly and with caution. Scan your eyes across traffic in both directions.

questions.question: You are driving on a divided multilane highway and see or hear the signal of an approaching emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Disregard the signal if there are other lanes available for the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop as quickly as you can.
questions.answerC: Slow down, move your vehicle to provide a clear path for the emergency vehicle, and stop.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get out of the way of the emergency vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an emergency vehicle, you must slow down, provide a clear path for the vehicle, and stop. Don't try to outdrive the emergency vehicle.

questions.question: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or using a guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Take the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Proceed normally.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: Roads freeze quickly when they are:
questions.answerA: Flat.
questions.answerB: Curvy.
questions.answerC: In the sun.
questions.explanation: In cold or wet weather, you should take special care on sections of road that are shaded by trees or buildings. These areas freeze more quickly than the rest of the road and are the last parts of the road to dry.

questions.question: Two vehicles are driving side by side ahead of your vehicle and you are in a hurry. You should:
questions.answerA: Drive closely behind the vehicle in the left lane and flash your headlights.
questions.answerB: Drive closely behind the vehicle in the right lane.
questions.answerC: Drive in either lane with a two-second time interval between you and the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: Quickly switch back and forth between the lanes.
questions.explanation: Always allow at least two seconds of space between you and the vehicle in front of you. This allows you room to react to the actions of other drivers. You must always leave adequate space between vehicles, regardless of if you are in a hurry or not.

questions.question: Certain highway signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerA: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Failure to comply is subject to penalty.

questions.question: Regulatory signs:
questions.answerA: Are placed in every location where there is a present danger.
questions.answerB: Indicate what a driver must or must not do.
questions.answerC: Are diamond-shaped and yellow or green.
questions.answerD: May warn drivers that they are approaching a school zone.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are often rectangular and white with black markings and are used to indicate what things a driver must or must not do in a designated area. They may display speed limits, prohibit passing or turning, or clarify any other driving regulation.

questions.question: You wish to drive a heavy truck in Hawaii. You must:
questions.answerA: Be at least 21 years old.
questions.answerB: Have a valid driver license for the category of vehicle you wish to drive.
questions.answerC: Have no special qualifications.
questions.answerD: Drive the truck only on truck routes.
questions.explanation: Drivers of large vehicles must hold a valid license for the category of vehicle being driven. Information on all types of driver licenses may be found in the Hawaii Drivers Manual.

questions.question: When you park uphill on a street with a curb:
questions.answerA: Keep the front wheel straight and set the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn the back wheels into the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on an incline where there is a curb, you should turn your wheels sharply to the left, away from the curb. This way, if your brakes fail, your vehicle will not roll into traffic.

questions.question: Motorcycles are entitled to:
questions.answerA: The bicycle lane.
questions.answerB: The same full lane width as other motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Half the width of a lane.
questions.explanation: Lane usage for the motorcyclist is critical. Motorcycles are entitled to the same full lane width as all other vehicles.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Emergency vehicles ahead.
questions.answerB: Uncontrolled intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Four-way stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a traffic signal is ahead.

questions.question: Anything that requires you to ____ could cause you to crash.
questions.answerA: Take your eyes off the road
questions.answerB: Take your hands off the wheel
questions.answerC: Take your attention away from the task of driving
questions.explanation: Anything that causes you to take your attention away from driving, take your eyes off the road, and/or take your hands off the wheel is a distraction.

questions.question: From the center lane, which maneuver(s) can you perform?
questions.answerA: You may make left turns.
questions.answerB: You may make U-turns.
questions.answerC: You may pass slow-moving traffic.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates where a lane is reserved for the exclusive use of left-turning vehicles from either direction. Such a lane may not be used for passing or for through-traffic.

questions.question: If not otherwise prohibited by a sign, a driver stopped at a solid red traffic light may:
questions.answerA: Turn right after yielding to other traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Never turn right.
questions.answerC: Turn right at any time.
questions.answerD: Turn right only after sounding their horn.
questions.explanation: After stopping at an intersection with a solid red traffic light, you may turn right unless a sign prohibits such movement. You must yield to all pedestrians and all vehicles before making such a turn.

questions.question: You are driving when your power steering stops working. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn and turn off the ignition.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights and brace yourself.
questions.answerC: Work hard to steer, reduce your speed, drive to a safe area, and stop.
questions.explanation: If your power steering stops working, additional effort will be required to maintain steering control. Reduce your speed and pull off the roadway to stop in a safe area.

questions.question: A flashing red light on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal is broken.
questions.answerC: You do not have to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means the same thing as a stop sign. If you encounter a flashing red light, you should come to a complete stop, yield to appropriate traffic and pedestrians, and only proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a detour ahead.
questions.answerB: You must stop for flaggers.
questions.answerC: The road ahead is closed to traffic.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead is undergoing maintenance.
questions.explanation: Construction and maintenance signs are orange-colored and are used to notify drivers of unusual or potentially dangerous conditions in or near work areas. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a construction zone and that they should prepare to lower their speed and drive with extraordinary caution.

questions.question: Which of the following does not happen after drinking?
questions.answerA: Your reflexes and reaction time slow down.
questions.answerB: Your judgement of speed and distance is distorted.
questions.answerC: You are less alert.
questions.answerD: You calm down and can concentrate better.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces your reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights, and often reduces your inhibitions and makes you more likely to take risks.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Road widens ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane reduction; the right lane ends soon.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.answerD: Lane reduction; the left lane ends soon.
questions.explanation: This sign indicate that the right lane ends ahead.

questions.question: Which of the following lights indicates that you should slow down and proceed with caution at an intersection?
questions.answerA: A flashing yellow light
questions.answerB: A flashing red light
questions.answerC: A solid yellow light
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light at an intersection indicates that drivers must slow down, proceed with caution, and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that the divided highway is about to end.

questions.question: Distracted driving may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Eating, drinking, or smoking.
questions.answerB: Talking or texting on a cellular phone.
questions.answerC: Changing a radio station or CD.
questions.explanation: It is estimated that drivers make 200 decisions for every mile traveled, making it vital that drivers focus their full attention on the task of driving. Performing any additional task can create a dangerous distraction.

questions.question: An inattentive driver is a driver who:
questions.answerA: Stares at objects off the roadway or daydreams while driving.
questions.answerB: Maintains eye contact during a conversation with a passenger while driving.
questions.answerC: Only watches the vehicle ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. Continue scanning the road, checking your mirrors, and looking at the instrument panel at regular intervals. Developing these safe habits will keep you attentive as a driver.

questions.question: You are driving forward out of your driveway. You:
questions.answerA: Must come to a complete stop before crossing the sidewalk area.
questions.answerB: Must slow down before crossing the sidewalk area.
questions.answerC: Have the right-of-way over pedestrians in the sidewalk area.
questions.answerD: Can cross the sidewalk area without stopping if you first honk your horn.
questions.explanation: When driving forward out of a driveway, always stop before entering the road. The stop should be made before crossing the sidewalk area. Failure to stop is unlawful.

questions.question: To enter a freeway:
questions.answerA: Signal, yield to existing traffic, and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving.
questions.answerB: Signal and enter the freeway. Freeway traffic must yield.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly so you can check traffic.
questions.answerD: Always come to a complete stop first.
questions.explanation: When merging into traffic, you should signal and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving. Always yield to other traffic when entering a roadway.

questions.question: A bicyclist who doesn’t obey traffic laws:
questions.answerA: Is in the right because bicyclists don’t have to obey traffic laws.
questions.answerB: Can be ticketed.
questions.answerC: Will always receive a warning from law enforcement.
questions.explanation: All bicyclists have the same rights, duties, and responsibilities as drivers of motor vehicles. Motorists and bicyclists who do not obey traffic laws can be ticketed.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Winding road.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a low ground railroad crossing. Where this sign is present, railroad tracks cross the road at a steep slope and the bottom of low vehicles may drag or get caught on the tracks.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection or into any driveway, you:
questions.answerA: Should leave room on your right for other vehicles to pass.
questions.answerB: Must yield to vehicles approaching from the opposite direction.
questions.answerC: Must not cross any solid yellow line.
questions.answerD: Must not block vehicles approaching from behind your vehicle.
questions.explanation: When turning left, yield to all oncoming traffic that is close enough to be a hazard. You may complete the turn only when the opposite lane is free of hazardous traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming intersection.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady green arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn in the direction of the arrow after yielding to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerD: May drive straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: A green arrow displayed on a traffic signal tells drivers that they may turn in the direction of the arrow. You must be in the proper lane for such a turn. Yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians already in the intersection.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.answerD: Be alert for construction workers on the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. Drivers should be cautious when driving where pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other:
questions.answerA: It is always safe to proceed after one train passes.
questions.answerB: You must always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: When one train passes, look for another train on the other track before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn as you cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other, watch for a second approaching train after one train passes. Do not begin to cross the tracks until you’re sure no train is approaching from either direction on either track.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto the shoulder of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake hard and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Stop your car on the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Slow down and very carefully turn back onto the pavement.
questions.answerD: Maintain your speed and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto a low shoulder, you should reduce your speed without braking and very carefully turn back onto the pavement. Be aware of any nearby traffic when re-entering the road.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Heavy traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign means that it is not safe for drivers to enter the indicated road or driveway from their current direction. If you come across one of these signs, you should immediately turn around and drive a different way.

questions.question: To ensure that your physical condition does not cause you to drive in an unsafe manner, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep physically fit and have regular physical examinations.
questions.answerB: Know the effect of any medicine on your driving ability.
questions.answerC: Drive within your physical limitations.
questions.explanation: Your physical condition has an important bearing on your ability to drive safely. Drivers should be aware of their physical limitations and only drive if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You are turning onto a two-lane road divided by a broken yellow line. You know immediately that:
questions.answerA: You are on a two-way road.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way road.
questions.answerC: The road is under repair.
questions.answerD: You must stay to the left of the broken yellow lines.
questions.explanation: Yellow centerlines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Broken lines may be crossed to pass slower-moving traffic when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing warning sign:
questions.answerA: Be ready to drive faster than the train.
questions.answerB: Be prepared to stop if a train is nearby.
questions.answerC: Look for a way around any lowered gates.
questions.answerD: Assume no trains are nearby and continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossing warning signs are used to warn drivers of the possibility of a train. Drivers should obey all railroad crossing warning signs and never go around barriers or disregard the warning sign.

questions.question: If you change your name, you must notify the county examiner of drivers within:
questions.answerA: 60 days.
questions.answerB: 20 days.
questions.answerC: 10 days.
questions.explanation: Whenever you change your address, you must provide the county examiner of drivers with your new address, your name, and driver license number. This must be done in writing and within 30 days of the change. A change of name requires you to appear in person at the appropriate office within 30 days with proof of the change.

questions.question: You are coming to a railroad crossing where the crossing signals are flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for a train.
questions.answerB: Slow down and look for a train.
questions.answerC: Look for a train, then speed up.
questions.answerD: Do what the vehicle ahead of you does.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must stop your vehicle no closer than 15 feet from the nearest rail if an installed electric or mechanical signal is giving warning of an approaching train. Be aware of other warning signs that may indicate an oncoming train, including seeing a lowered crossing gate or hearing an oncoming train.

questions.question: When you take a road test for a driver license:
questions.answerA: You must provide the vehicle.
questions.answerB: The vehicle must be in safe operating condition, free of safety defects.
questions.answerC: You must be accompanied to the testing station by a licensed driver.
questions.explanation: You must be accompanied to the testing station by a licensed driver and provide a vehicle in safe operating condition with a current safety inspection certificate and no-fault insurance card. All vehicle safety defects must be corrected prior to taking the test.

questions.question: You may cross solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerB: During daylight hours only.
questions.answerC: At any time.
questions.explanation: As a general rule, broken traffic lines may be crossed but solid lines may not. Solid yellow lines may be crossed only when the driver is making a turn.

questions.question: Signs that are colored orange are:
questions.answerA: Work zone signs.
questions.answerB: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerC: School zone signs.
questions.explanation: Highway work zones are established according to the type of work underway along the roadway. Signs in work areas are typically diamond-shaped, orange, have black letters or symbols, and serve as a warning that people are working on or near the highway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed at the beginning of one-way streets and ramps to indicate that you must not continue driving in your current direction.

questions.question: Which of the following equipment may you have installed on your private vehicle?
questions.answerA: A blue light visible outside of the vehicle
questions.answerB: A bell, exhaust whistle, or siren
questions.answerC: A muffler cut-out or by-pass
questions.explanation: Adding a bell, exhaust whistle, or siren to your motor vehicle is prohibited. You may not add a red light that is visible from the front of your vehicle or a blue light that is visible outside of the vehicle. You may not add a muffler cut-out, muffler bypass, or any muffler that makes more noise than the vehicle's original equipment.

questions.question: When driving in rain, you must:
questions.answerA: Use low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Use high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use parking lights.
questions.explanation: In rainy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: You are borrowing an unfamiliar vehicle from a friend. You should:
questions.answerA: Not put too much thought into it because all vehicles are the same.
questions.answerB: Hide from your friend that you are unfamiliar with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Disregard any obvious defects to avoid embarrassing your friend.
questions.answerD: Take a few minutes before driving to familiarize yourself with the operation and location of all the vehicle’s equipment.
questions.explanation: When driving an unfamiliar vehicle, take a few minutes before driving to familiarize yourself with the location and operation of the turn signals, hazard warning signals, headlights and beam selector, windshield wipers and washers, brakes, gear selector, and horn. Any defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: When faced with an oncoming car to the left and a bicyclist to the right, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull onto the shoulder.
questions.answerB: Split the difference.
questions.answerC: Let the car pass and then pass the bike.
questions.explanation: When there is more than one potential hazard on the road, you should ensure that you only have to deal with one of them at a time. For example, when there is a bicyclist on the right that you want to pass and an oncoming car to the left, you should not try to squeeze between both at the same time. Instead, let the oncoming car pass, and then pass the bicyclist.

questions.question: If you are driving in another driver's blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Move forward or drop back so the other driver can see you.
questions.answerB: Keep a steady pace.
questions.answerC: Stay in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerD: Honk to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Do not drive in someone else’s blind spot. Move forward or drop back so that the other driver can see you.

questions.question: When turning or changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Always signal your intentions, even when no visible traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Signal only if there is visible traffic.
questions.answerC: Signal only when driving at night.
questions.answerD: Signal only when driving in heavy traffic at night.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions when changing lanes, turning, or pulling away from a curb. Do not allow yourself to become lazy and form the bad habit of not following this law.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Flash your lights.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the pedestrian cross.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop whenever you see pedestrians walking on or crossing the roadway. Be particularly careful where children are present. Always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing in a crosswalk.

questions.question: You must pull over to the edge of the road and allow an emergency vehicle to pass:
questions.answerA: Regardless of your direction.
questions.answerB: Only if it is following you.
questions.answerC: Only if it is approaching you from the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: You must pull over to the right edge of the road and stop for an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, regardless of whether it is approaching you from behind or from the opposite direction.

questions.question: A seat belt should be adjusted so that it:
questions.answerA: Is loose.
questions.answerB: Is buckled snugly across your hip bones and lower abdomen.
questions.answerC: Is hidden beneath the seat.
questions.answerD: Keeps the seat belt buzzer or light from operating.
questions.explanation: Lap belts should fit snugly across your hip bones and the lower part of your abdomen. Shoulder belts should sit comfortably so that you can insert your fist between the belt and your chest.

questions.question: When towing a trailer large enough to obstruct your inside rearview mirror, you are required to:
questions.answerA: Have an outside rearview mirror installed on the driver’s side of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Have an outside rearview mirror installed on the side of your vehicle opposite the driver.
questions.answerC: Have outside rearview mirrors installed on both sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Have a person in the vehicle to clear you for right turns.
questions.explanation: If you are towing a trailer that is large enough to obstruct your view of the road through your inside rearview mirror, you must have outside rearview mirrors of proper size installed on your vehicle. These rearview mirrors should be added to both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: To reduce the effects of headlight glare at night, you should look:
questions.answerA: Straight ahead.
questions.answerB: Over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: At the center of the road
questions.answerD: To the right edge of the road.
questions.explanation: If oncoming drivers do not dim their headlights for you, keep your eyes on the right side of the road ahead. Do not look directly at the oncoming headlights because the glare may blind you for several seconds.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: When you see or hear an emergency vehicle coming, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately and let the vehicle pass.
questions.answerB: Drive as far toward the right side of the road as is safe and stop.
questions.answerC: Proceed slowly and permit the vehicle to pass.
questions.answerD: Keep moving slowly, staying to the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: When driving on a two-lane roadway or undivided highway, you must yield to an emergency vehicle using its lights and/or siren, regardless of the direction from which it is approaching. Immediately drive as near as possible to the right side of the road and stop, taking care not to stop within an intersection.

questions.question: You are entering a crowded freeway. What should you do to merge into traffic?
questions.answerA: Use your side and rearview mirrors and check your blind spots.
questions.answerB: Use the acceleration lane to adjust your speed to match the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.answerC: Yield to traffic already on the freeway.
questions.explanation: Use the entrance ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic and yield to traffic already using the freeway. Before entering traffic, use your mirrors and check your blind spots to verify that you have room to safely merge.

questions.question: You come to an intersection displaying a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are also approaching the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop only if other cars are already within the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light has the same meaning as a stop sign. You must stop, yield the right-of-way, and go once it is safe.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately.
questions.answerB: Help the injured.
questions.answerC: Call the police.
questions.explanation: If involved in an accident, you should stop your vehicle immediately. If possible, move the vehicle out of the way of traffic. Call the nearest police agency and ask for an ambulance, if necessary. Do not move the injured unnecessarily, but attempt to stop severe bleeding with direct pressure. Wait for emergency vehicles to arrive.

questions.question: When you are being tailgated:
questions.answerA: Move over to the right, if there is an open lane to your right.
questions.answerB: If there is not an open lane to your right, wait until the way is clear ahead and reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerC: Never slow down abruptly.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated by another driver and there is a right lane, move over to the right. If there is no right lane, wait until the road ahead is clear and then reduce your speed slowly. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you. Never slow down abruptly as this will only increase the risk of your vehicle being hit from behind.

questions.question: What color are pavement markings that separate traffic lanes moving in opposite direction?
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerB: White
questions.answerC: Yellow and white
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used in the center of the road to separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turns.
questions.answerB: Right turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding seat belts and child restraints in vehicles?
questions.answerA: You should never place an infant or small child in the front seat of a vehicle with airbags.
questions.answerB: An airbag can be dangerous to an infant or small child, even in a low-speed collision.
questions.answerC: You should always make sure all your passengers are using a seat belt or child restraint.
questions.explanation: Before you drive, always fasten your seat belt and make sure all your passengers are using seat belts or child restraints. Studies have shown that if you use seat belts, your chances of being hurt or killed in a traffic crash are greatly reduced. Children age 12 and under should always ride properly restrained in a rear seat. Never put a rear-facing infant restraint in the front seat of a vehicle with a front passenger airbag.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks under 18,000 lbs. allowed.
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill ahead.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerA: Either side
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: When approaching a steady green traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, unless there are vehicles or pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop if a police officer is nearby.
questions.answerC: Treat the intersection like a four-way stop.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a steady green traffic light, yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and vehicles still in the intersection. You may continue driving, but should approach the intersection at a speed that will allow you to slow down and stop if the light changes before you get there.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Intersection.
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that an intersection with a crossing road is ahead.

questions.question: What should you do if your accelerator sticks while you are driving?
questions.answerA: Reach down and attempt to pull it up.
questions.answerB: Shift to park.
questions.answerC: Shift to neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake.
questions.explanation: If your accelerator sticks while you are driving, keep your eyes on the road. Quickly shift the vehicle into neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake pedal. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so and turn off the engine.

questions.question: Drivers must yield to a pedestrian:
questions.answerA: Even if the pedestrian crosses the street carelessly.
questions.answerB: Only when the pedestrian is in a crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Only if the pedestrian is on the same side of the road as the driver.
questions.answerD: If the pedestrian uses a hand signal to ask oncoming drivers to stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in the street, even if they are crossing against a red light or are otherwise being careless.

questions.question: A police officer asks you to take a test determining the amount of alcohol in your blood. You:
questions.answerA: Do not have to take the test if you can prove that you weren’t drinking
questions.answerB: Must take the test or risk losing your license.
questions.answerC: Do not have to take the test if you have not violated any traffic rule.
questions.answerD: Must take the test or risk a fine.
