questions.explanation: Any person operating a motor vehicle in Hawaii consents to having their blood alcohol content (BAC) tested when requested by law enforcement. Refusing to take a chemical test will result in the revocation of your license for a minimum of one year.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for trucks.
questions.answerB: Do not pass trucks.
questions.answerC: Truck parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a hill ahead.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid red arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Means that the traffic the arrow is pointing toward must stop.
questions.explanation: A solid red arrow in a traffic signal means the same thing as a circular red traffic light. When an arrow is red, traffic in the indicated lane must stop and may not turn in the direction that the arrow is pointing.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: In a curve or on a hill because the chance is small that another vehicle is coming.
questions.answerB: By using the shoulder of the highway.
questions.answerC: If your lane is next to a solid yellow line and the passing lane is clear ahead.
questions.explanation: You may not pass another vehicle on a hill or in a curve because you cannot see oncoming traffic and may cause a collision. Never pass another vehicle by driving onto the shoulder of a highway. Passing another vehicle by driving over a solid yellow line is prohibited.

questions.question: You are driving in moderate traffic on a four-lane highway behind a slow-moving vehicle. Before changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Signal your intentions for at least 100 feet.
questions.answerB: Make sure your blind spot is clear.
questions.answerC: Make sure there is sufficient room in traffic to make the move.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check highway and traffic conditions ahead, to the sides, and to the rear of your vehicle. After checking your mirrors, check your blind spot by turning your head and looking over your shoulder in the direction of your move. Signal your intention at least 100 feet before you start the lane change. Don't move into a space between vehicles if doing so would interfere with their safe following distances.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerA: The maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: Crossbuck signs indicate:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossings.
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: No passing zones.
questions.explanation: Crossbuck signs tell drivers to yield to trains at a railroad crossing. Drivers should not try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: When driving on wet pavement, it's important to remember:
questions.answerA: That pavement is especially slippery right after it starts to rain.
questions.answerB: That wet roads can cause hydroplaning.
questions.answerC: To give yourself additional space when coming to a stop.
questions.explanation: Wet roadway surfaces can be dangerously slick, especially immediately following a rainfall. When you are driving on wet roads, your vehicle is traveling on a thin layer of oil, dirt, and water. Slow down when there is heavy rain, standing water, or slush on the road to reduce the risk of your wheels losing traction on the slick surface.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerB: A steep grade is ahead.
questions.answerC: The overpass ahead has a low clearance.
questions.answerD: Two lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are about to merge.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. Do not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height indicated (in this case, 13 feet, 6 inches).

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Two-way left turn.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This sign tells drivers the direction in which they must drive when turning onto a one-way street.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: You are driving when it starts to sleet or snow. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep your windshield and mirrors clear.
questions.answerB: Allow additional distance between your vehicle and the vehicles that you are following.
questions.answerC: Approach all vehicles with caution.
questions.explanation: In snowy weather, keep your windshield and mirrors clear. Increase your following distance when driving in wet and cold weather because a slippery road surface will increase the distance needed for your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down or stop.
questions.answerB: Stop, if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided sign always means "stop." You must come to a complete stop and wait for any vehicles or pedestrians to clear the way before proceeding.

questions.question: The most common color of warning signs is:
questions.answerA: Red.
questions.answerB: Yellow.
questions.answerC: Green.
questions.explanation: Most warning signs are diamond-shaped and yellow with black markings. These signs warn drivers about unexpected conditions that may not be readily apparent.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle on any public street or highway, you must:
questions.answerA: Show your driver license to law enforcement upon request.
questions.answerB: Carry your driver license with you.
questions.answerC: Have a valid driver license.
questions.explanation: You must have a valid driver license on you at all times when operating a motor vehicle. You must present it to a police officer when asked to do so.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: To help prevent crashes, you should:
questions.answerA: Communicate with other road users.
questions.answerB: Ignore other drivers on the road.
questions.answerC: Drive only on side streets and back roads.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen because one driver does something that other road users are not expecting. You should communicate with other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians by doing things like signaling when slowing down, stopping, or changing direction. Use your emergency signals or horn when appropriate.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: How can you help prevent rear-end collisions?
questions.answerA: Avoid sudden stops.
questions.answerB: Before stopping, check your mirrors and blind spots for traffic.
questions.answerC: Release the gas pedal and let your vehicle slow before applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Stopping suddenly can make it difficult for drivers behind you to avoid a rear-end collision. When stopping, release the accelerator to allow your vehicle to slow. Press the brake pedal by applying steady pressure, activating your brake lights and causing the vehicle to stop smoothly.

questions.question: If you change your address, you must notify the county examiner of drivers:
questions.answerA: In writing, within 30 days.
questions.answerB: In writing, within 10 days.
questions.answerC: In person, within 10 days.
questions.explanation: Whenever you change your address, you must provide the county examiner of drivers with your new address, your name, and driver license number. This must be done in writing and within 30 days of the change. A change of name requires you to appear in person at the appropriate office within 30 days with proof of the change.

questions.question: To avoid collisions with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Adjust your rearview mirrors every few minutes.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Before turning or changing lanes, turn your head and glance over your shoulder in the direction of your move to see if your blind spot is clear. Never rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: When your driver license expires, you may:
questions.answerA: Drive during the 90-day grace period.
questions.answerB: Drive as long as you are accompanied by a licensed driver.
questions.answerC: Renew your driver license within a year of the expiration date but may not drive with the expired license.
questions.answerD: Drive to and from work only.
questions.explanation: You may renew your license within six months of its expiration date. Every Hawaii state driver license is void after the expiration date, with no grace period. Your license may be renewed within a year of the expiration date.

questions.question: If you drive a heavy truck or bus on the highway, you:
questions.answerA: Are responsible for giving proper consideration to other highway users.
questions.answerB: Can use that additional size of your vehicle to your advantage in traffic.
questions.answerC: Can expect smaller vehicles to stay out of your way.
questions.answerD: Are responsible only for your truck and its cargo.
questions.explanation: Due to their size and weight, large trucks and buses can cause great damage and injury when involved in an accident. The drivers of these vehicles must be constantly aware of the limitations and potential of their vehicles and recognize their responsibility to give proper consideration to other highway users, as well as to their passengers and cargo.

questions.question: When encountering an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Avoid eye contact, slow down, and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Cut them off to slow them down.
questions.answerC: Retaliate by tailgating them.
questions.answerD: Make sure they know you disapprove of their behavior.
questions.explanation: If another driver is threatening you or intentionally driving dangerously around you, remain calm and try to put as much distance between the two of you as possible. Slow down and let them pass. Do not make eye contact and do not make obscene gestures.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerA: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver cuts you off, you should:
questions.answerA: Call the police immediately.
questions.answerB: Stay calm and move out of the aggressive driver's way.
questions.answerC: Flash your vehicle's lights to let the aggressive driver know he is wrong.
questions.answerD: Use a driving action of your own to get back at the aggressive driver.
questions.explanation: If an aggressive driver cuts you off on the roadway, stay calm and get out of their way. Trying to get even with an aggressive driver risks escalating the situation and increasing the danger.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerB: Double curve.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.

questions.question: If you are driving on a one-way street and an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights approaches your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive with your flashers turned on.
questions.answerB: Drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.answerD: Slow down until the vehicle passes you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its lights or siren approaches while you are driving on a one-way street, you must drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerB: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. Only cross white lane lines if the lines are broken.

questions.question: You are driving on a highway divided by two solid yellow lines. You may:
questions.answerA: Cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.
questions.answerB: Cross these lines to pass other vehicles, but only if there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Cross these lines under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: Cross these lines only to make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines are used to mark roadways where passing is prohibited from both directions. You may cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.

questions.question: Increasing your vehicle’s speed:
questions.answerA: Increases your field of vision.
questions.answerB: Decreases your field of vision.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to see cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your field of vision.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the smaller your field of vision becomes. As your speed increases and your field of vision decreases, you must be extra alert to potential hazards.

questions.question: If you need to drive in foggy weather:
questions.answerA: Turn on your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights.
questions.answerC: It is okay to drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerD: Do not drive at a speed above 10 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: You are required to use your headlights during the day when visibility is reduced to 500 feet or less. When you first turn on your headlights, be sure they are adjusted to the low beam setting. Using high beams in fog or rain will cause the light to reflect back into your eyes, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: This green arrow on a lane use control signal means:
questions.answerA: You may use this lane.
questions.answerB: No traffic is allowed in this lane.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: You must merge into this lane.
questions.explanation: A steady downward green arrow over a traffic lane means you may use the lane indicated.

questions.question: Drugs may interfere with a person’s ability to drive safely:
questions.answerA: Only if the drugs are not prescribed by a doctor.
questions.answerB: Only when taken while drinking.
questions.answerC: Only when the person is driving at night.
questions.answerD: Even if the drugs are prescribed by a doctor.
questions.explanation: Many medicines interfere with a person’s ability to drive safely. Before beginning a regimen of any medication, it is important to ask your doctor about possible side effects that could affect your driving ability.

questions.question: If you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must not pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: May pass a slow-moving vehicle if you can do so quickly.
questions.answerC: May pass if you know the road ahead.
questions.answerD: May pass, but only at night.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are white, rectangular signs with black markings. Drivers must obey the instructions posted on all regulatory signs. Where this sign is posted, it is prohibited for drivers to pass one another.

questions.question: When approaching an uncontrolled intersection, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Maintain their speed and proceed.
questions.answerB: Stop at the intersection, check in all directions, and proceed.
questions.answerC: Yield to all other drivers.
questions.explanation: At an intersection where there is no stop sign or traffic signal, you should yield to a vehicle approaching the intersection from the right. However, always be prepared to yield to avoid a crash. Do this by taking your foot off the accelerator, covering the brake, and looking left, right, and left again.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get some coffee.
questions.answerB: Open your window.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: What does a flashing yellow traffic light mean?
questions.answerA: Merging traffic
questions.answerB: Proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light indicates that you should drive with caution.

questions.question: A good defensive driver:
questions.answerA: Drives slowly at all times.
questions.answerB: Looks out for the actions of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Travels at a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even the most experienced drivers can be distracted while driving. A defensive driver looks out for the actions of other drivers and anticipates potential problems.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Narrow bridge ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: Industrial area.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: Bicyclists:
questions.answerA: May ride side-by-side on roadways.
questions.answerB: May ride two abreast on bike paths, except where signs indicate otherwise.
questions.answerC: Have the right-of-way over pedestrians.
questions.answerD: May ride attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: On the roadway, bicyclists must ride single file. They may ride two abreast on a bicycle lane or path if it is wide enough that doing so will not impede traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This warning sign indicates that drivers are about to encounter a divided highway.

questions.question: An intersection has no traffic signs or signals. You arrive at the same time as a vehicle to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up and get through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and yield to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Drive into the intersection and make the other vehicle stop.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn and drive through the intersection.
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Once the vehicle on the right has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: A left curve is ahead.
questions.answerB: A series of curves is ahead.
questions.answerC: An S-curve is ahead.
questions.answerD: The road will be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that especially slippery conditions exist when the road is wet.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Road construction ahead.
questions.answerB: The road ahead curves left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves right, then left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left. You should slow down to be able to negotiate these curves safely.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal means that a ____ light will soon appear.
questions.answerA: Flashing yellow
questions.answerB: Steady green
questions.answerC: Steady red
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light on a traffic signal indicates that a steady red light will soon appear.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down. If possible, change lanes so you will not drive next to the stopped emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane and continue to drive at the same speed.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to quickly pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space. If there is only one lane moving in your direction, or if changing lanes would be unsafe, you must slow down to a speed below the posted speed limit and give the stationary vehicle as much room as possible. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerA: Turn left.
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: When making a turn or lane change, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal immediately before the turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal 100 feet before the turn or lane change, even if no other vehicles are around.
questions.answerC: Signal 100 feet before the turn or lane change, but only when driving in traffic.
questions.explanation: When slowing down, turning, or changing lanes, you should communicate with other drivers. Signal every time you want to change lanes or turn , even if there are no other vehicles in sight.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: A leaking exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Cause excessive oil use.
questions.answerB: Require your vehicle to have a tune-up sooner than normal.
questions.answerC: Make you drowsy while driving.
questions.answerD: Set grass fires on country roads.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system helps remove toxic gases, reduce the noise, and cool the hot gases coming from a running engine. Fumes from a leaky exhaust system can cause death in a very short time. They can also make you drowsy while driving.

questions.question: It is important to slow down:
questions.answerA: On narrow or winding roads.
questions.answerB: At intersections or railroad crossings.
questions.answerC: When the road is wet or slippery.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down when driving on narrow or winding roads, near intersections, near railroad crossings, on hills, in sharp or blind curves, where there are pedestrians or driving hazards, and when the roads are wet or slippery.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: You experience an incident at work that has left you feeling angry. When you get to your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Play the radio loudly so you won’t think about it.
questions.answerB: Drive fast on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.answerC: Take a few minutes to cool off before you begin your drive home.
questions.answerD: Stop at your favorite bar and have a few drinks before driving home.
questions.explanation: Persons who are upset, angry, or otherwise distracted by their emotions should take time to cool off before driving a car. Taking out frustrations or anger while driving is exercising very poor judgment and is very dangerous to both the driver and others on the road.

questions.question: Which of the following are used on some highways to direct drivers into the proper lanes for turning?
questions.answerA: Flashing red lights
questions.answerB: Flashing yellow lights
questions.answerC: White lines on the side of the road
questions.answerD: White arrows in the middle of the lanes
questions.explanation: Arrows may be used to indicate which lanes should be used for specific purposes, such as driving straight or making a turn.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane ends, merge left.
questions.answerC: Turn around.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a roundabout is ahead. Enter a roundabout at a low speed and yield to existing traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Keep right.
questions.answerB: Keep left.
questions.answerC: Pass with caution.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. The road splits into two one-way roadways separated by a median or divider. You must keep to the right.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle on any public street or highway, you must:
questions.answerA: Show your driver license to law enforcement upon request.
questions.answerB: Carry your driver license with you.
questions.answerC: Have a valid driver license.
questions.explanation: You must have a valid driver license on you at all times when operating a motor vehicle. You must present it to a police officer when asked to do so.

questions.question: You are driving along a street and hear a siren. You cannot immediately see the emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep driving until you see the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Pull to the curb and look to see if it is on your street.
questions.answerC: Slow down. Don't stop until you see it.
questions.answerD: Speed up and turn at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: If you hear a siren or an air horn close by but do not know exactly where the emergency vehicle is, safely pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure it is not headed toward you.

questions.question: When turning or changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Always signal your intentions, even when no visible traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Signal only if there is visible traffic.
questions.answerC: Signal only when driving at night.
questions.answerD: Signal only when driving in heavy traffic at night.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions when changing lanes, turning, or pulling away from a curb. Do not allow yourself to become lazy and form the bad habit of not following this law.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerA: Turn off all your lights.
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights only.
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to avoid the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle immediately and prevent them from passing.
questions.answerC: Make every effort to give the emergency vehicle a clear path of travel.
questions.answerD: Signal to the emergency vehicle when it is clear for them to pass you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you must make every effort to give them a clear path of travel. If it is safe to do so, pull your vehicle to the side of the road to give the emergency vehicle an open pathway.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and another person is injured. You should:
questions.answerA: Moved the injured away from the scene immediately.
questions.answerB: Always leave the injured where they are.
questions.answerC: Not move the injured unnecessarily. Keep the injured warm and administer first aid.
questions.explanation: After an accident, do not move the injured unnecessarily. Unskilled handling can make serious injuries out of minor ones. Keep the injured warm until skilled help arrives. If there is severe bleeding, attempt to stop the flow of blood with direct pressure.

questions.question: When preparing to turn left, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Slow down gradually while checking their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Move into the left lane.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming vehicles and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: As you approach a left turn, signal your intentions three to five seconds in advance. Continually check your rearview mirror as you gradually slow down. On a multilane road, move into the left lane before reaching the intersection where you plan to turn. Yield to traffic and pedestrians and turn when your path is clear.

questions.question: If not otherwise prohibited by a sign, a driver stopped at a solid red traffic light may:
questions.answerA: Turn right after yielding to other traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Never turn right.
questions.answerC: Turn right at any time.
questions.answerD: Turn right only after sounding their horn.
questions.explanation: After stopping at an intersection with a solid red traffic light, you may turn right unless a sign prohibits such movement. You must yield to all pedestrians and all vehicles before making such a turn.

questions.question: The most important thing to remember about speed management and curves is that you must:
questions.answerA: Drive at the posted speed limit as you enter the curve, then slow down at the sharpest part of the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow down before you enter the curve.
questions.answerC: Accelerate gently before you enter the curve.
questions.answerD: Drive at the posted speed limit before, throughout, and after the curve.
questions.explanation: The most important thing to remember about driving in curves is that your vehicle’s inertia may make it difficult to turn. To maintain control, it is essential that you slow down before entering the curve.

questions.question: When passing a large vehicle, the driver of a small vehicle must be prepared for:
questions.answerA: Loud noises.
questions.answerB: Excess air pollution.
questions.answerC: Wind gusts produced by the large vehicle.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles can cause wind gusts with a force great enough to cause direction changes in smaller vehicles. Drivers of small vehicles should be prepared to take proper corrective steering action when approaching or passing large vehicles that are moving at or near maximum speeds.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerA: No passing zone
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: The best way to deal with tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerB: Slam on your brakes to get the other driver to back off.
questions.answerC: Change lanes or gradually slow down to encourage them to pass.
questions.explanation: Check the traffic behind you several times a minute to know if another driver is tailgating, approaching too fast, or trying to pass. If another car is following you too closely, slow down and let it pass. Most rear-end collisions are caused by vehicles following too closely.

questions.question: You come to an intersection with a flashing red light. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive carefully through the  intersection.
questions.answerB: Turn either right or left, since the road is blocked ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop at the intersection and wait for a flashing green light.
questions.answerD: Stop at the intersection, then proceed as traffic allows.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must come to a full stop, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: You are late to work and in a hurry. Before you back into the street, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn.
questions.answerB: Check for children and other objects around your car.
questions.answerC: Rev your engine so that animals will get out of the way.
questions.answerD: Check for traffic before getting into your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Backing is a dangerous maneuver due to the restricted visibility and should be done with great caution. Exercise extraordinary caution when backing up in residential areas. Children often play behind and between parked vehicles.

questions.question: A police officer directs you to drive through a red light. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Stop and then proceed.
questions.answerB: Wait for the green light.
questions.answerC: Proceed as directed by the officer.
questions.explanation: You must obey all lawful orders and directions given by police officers. If a police officer indicates that you should continue through a red light, follow the instruction.

questions.question: Roads become very slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining for an hour or more.
questions.answerB: The day after it rains.
questions.answerC: For the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm.
questions.answerD: Right after the rain has stopped.
questions.explanation: Pavement can become very slippery within the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm because the rain causes oil in the asphalt to rise to the surface of the road. This problem becomes even worse in hot weather. The heat combined with the water causes more oil to rise to the road surface.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that pavement is slippery when wet. In wet conditions, you should reduce your speed, avoid braking or changing direction suddenly, and increase the distance between your vehicle and the one ahead.

questions.question: Who must yield when a driver is turning and a pedestrian is crossing without a traffic light?
questions.answerA: Whoever started moving last
questions.answerB: The driver
questions.answerC: Whoever is slower
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians when they are crossing at any intersection without a traffic light, whether or not there is a crosswalk.

questions.question: All headlights on your vehicle must work properly and be correctly adjusted:
questions.answerA: Only when you plan to drive in a city.
questions.answerB: At all times.
questions.answerC: Only when driving on freeways.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's headlights are critical to safely driving during the night, in rainy weather, in fog, and through tunnels. They must work properly and be correctly adjusted at all times.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle on a road with two lanes traveling in opposite directions, you should:
questions.answerA: Return to the driving lane when there's enough room between you and the vehicle you passed.
questions.answerB: Remain in the left lane if you intend to turn left.
questions.answerC: Return to the right side of the roadway immediately.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on a two-lane roadway, you must return to the right side of the roadway when there is enough room between you and the vehicle you have passed.

questions.question: Traffic regulations require drivers to display a turn signal for at least ____ before making a turn or lane change.
questions.answerA: 50 feet
questions.answerB: 75 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.explanation: Turn signals must be displayed for at least 100 feet before changing lanes or turning. It is advisable to signal for a greater distance when driving at increased speeds.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn.
questions.answerB: No stopping.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow arrow indicates that a red arrow is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerA: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn.
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: The correct way to use a freeway exit ramp is to:
questions.answerA: Slow down before entering the exit ramp.
questions.answerB: Slow down once moving onto the exit ramp.
questions.answerC: Keep your speed constant once in the exit ramp.
questions.answerD: Pass slower traffic in the exit ramp.
questions.explanation: When using a freeway exit ramp, do not slow down until you move onto the exit ramp.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerB: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. Only cross white lane lines if the lines are broken.

questions.question: If you are involved in an accident and the accident scene is not readily visible to oncoming traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Have someone warn approaching traffic.
questions.answerB: Let oncoming traffic watch out for themselves.
questions.answerC: Let the police handle everything.
questions.answerD: Assume other drivers will have heard the crash.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident and the accident scene is not readily visible to oncoming traffic, you should warn oncoming traffic. Have someone warn approaching drivers to prevent further damage. Keep a flashlight and flares in your vehicle for emergency use.

questions.question: A red flashing traffic light has the same meaning as a:
questions.answerA: Solid red light.
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Yield sign.
questions.explanation: A red flashing traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. When approaching a red flashing signal, come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so. A stop sign may sometimes also be posted where this signal is located.

questions.question: You should be cautious when passing a bicycle because:
questions.answerA: You are moving faster than the bicycle.
questions.answerB: The bicycle always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic may not see you pull out to pass the bicycle.
questions.answerD: The cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road.
questions.explanation: You should always be cautious when passing a bicycle because the cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road. Always be particularly careful when driving near bicyclists.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead curves right. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerC: Merge. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate that the road curves to the right ahead and that drivers should slow down to the safe speed indicated (in this case, 35 mph).

questions.question: Road rage and aggressive driving may be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Allowing extra travel time.
questions.answerB: Obeying posted speed limits.
questions.answerC: Using proper turn signals.
questions.explanation: As an increasing number of drivers populate the roadways, road rage becomes more prevalent. To help prevent road rage, a driver should use proper turn signals, obey posted speed limits, and allow plenty of travel time.

questions.question: A single broken yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks are permitted on an upcoming narrow bridge.
questions.answerB: The bridge ahead is open to one-way traffic only.
questions.answerC: The bridge ahead is wide enough for only one car at a time.
questions.answerD: The bridge ahead may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that an upcoming bridge may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck and that they should be careful.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Very uncommon.
questions.answerB: Extremely risky behavior.
questions.answerC: Nothing to be concerned about.
questions.answerD: No less safe than driving under any other conditions.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is extremely risky behavior that puts not only you and your passengers in danger, but also endangers pedestrians, bicyclists, and other motorists sharing the road. Focused attention on driving helps to prevent crashes.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Highway changes ahead and to the right.
questions.answerB: Hiking trails ahead and to the right.
questions.answerC: Hotel ahead and to the right.
questions.answerD: Hospital ahead and to the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that hospital emergency services are located to the right.

questions.question: Another driver is trying to pass your car. You should:
questions.answerA: Pull off the road.
questions.answerB: Signal to the other driver when it is safe for them to pass.
questions.answerC: Check for oncoming traffic and adjust your speed to allow safe passing.
questions.explanation: Keep right when another driver begins to pass you on the left. Check for oncoming traffic and adjust your speed to let the passing vehicle move back into the right lane as easily as possible.

questions.question: How can you lower the risk of hydroplaning?
questions.answerA: Do not speed when the roads are wet.
questions.answerB: Use tires with proper air pressure.
questions.answerC: Replace tires with bad tread.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning happens when a vehicle glides on top of a thin layer of water between its tires and the road. Tires with low air pressure or bad tread can increase the risk of hydroplaning. Speeding also increases the risk.

questions.question: A driver who is taking a non-prescription drug should:
questions.answerA: Read the labels on the drug before driving.
questions.answerB: Drink alcohol instead.
questions.answerC: Continue to drive regardless of any warning labels.
questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medications can affect your ability to drive safely. If you take medication, even a remedy for colds or allergies that is not prescribed, check the label for warnings about its effects. If you are unsure, ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving while on the medication.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are usually ____ and should always be obeyed.
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs regulate the movement of traffic. They are usually white with black markings and must always be obeyed by motorists.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerA: A bad driving habit.
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: You may pass a school bus from the front or rear on an undivided roadway:
questions.answerA: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerB: When the red lamps on the school bus are flashing.
questions.answerC: When the red lamps on the school bus are not flashing.
questions.answerD: At anytime, if you drive slowly.
questions.explanation: You may not pass a school bus on an undivided highway from either direction while the school bus is using its flashing red lights. If there are no flashing red lights, you may pass normally.

questions.question: When you are in a line of traffic that is crossing a railroad track that has no signals or gates:
questions.answerA: You have the right-of-way and do not need to check for trains.
questions.answerB: You may pass slower drivers while crossing the track.
questions.answerC: You need to make sure there is space for your vehicle to get all the way across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: If you are following another vehicle at a railroad crossing, check to make sure you have enough room to get all the way across before you drive onto the tracks. You should never try to pass another vehicle as you approach or cross a railroad crossing. Always check for trains before crossing any railroad tracks.

questions.question: Safety belts:
questions.answerA: Should be worn at all times when driving or riding in a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should be worn only when traveling at high speeds.
questions.answerC: Should be worn loosely.
questions.answerD: Can only prevent drivers from injury.
questions.explanation: Safety belts are life belts. They must be worn at all times when driving or riding in a vehicle. They are the most important personal safety item available in any vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If you drive past these signs, you are going the wrong way and are at risk of a head-on collision. You should cautiously turn around.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way road.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Exit.
questions.answerD: Sharp right turn in the road ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a sharp right turn ahead.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: A seat belt should be adjusted so that it:
questions.answerA: Is loose.
questions.answerB: Is buckled snugly across your hip bones and lower abdomen.
questions.answerC: Is hidden beneath the seat.
questions.answerD: Keeps the seat belt buzzer or light from operating.
questions.explanation: Lap belts should fit snugly across your hip bones and the lower part of your abdomen. Shoulder belts should sit comfortably so that you can insert your fist between the belt and your chest.

questions.question: When approaching a steady red traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Drive through the intersection if there is no crossing traffic.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Stop only if a police officer is nearby.
questions.explanation: A steady red traffic light indicates that drivers must come to a complete stop. Driving through a red light is against the law and is extremely dangerous. Drivers may turn right on a steady red light if there is no sign prohibiting a turn on red.

questions.question: Newer vehicles are equipped with a brake warning lamp on the instrument panel. This lamp:
questions.answerA: Should come on when the parking brake is released.
questions.answerB: Comes on to indicate that the brake system is defective.
questions.answerC: Will never come on.
questions.answerD: Comes on to indicate that the brake lights are operational.
questions.explanation: The brake warning lamp should go out when the parking brake is released. If it illuminates when the foot brake pedal is pressed, the brake system is defective and the vehicle should not be driven.

questions.question: The consumption of alcohol while taking drugs can:
questions.answerA: Decrease the effects of the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerB: Increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerC: Help cure your illness.
questions.explanation: The combination of alcohol and drugs, in some cases, can increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol. It can be unsafe to drive after consuming either alcohol or drugs and is even more dangerous after combining them.

questions.question: Alcohol causes:
questions.answerA: Loss of concentration.
questions.answerB: Poor coordination.
questions.answerC: Slower judgment.
questions.explanation: Consuming even a small amount of alcohol will impair your vision, judgment, concentration, and coordination.

questions.question: Which of the following about winter driving is not true?
questions.answerA: Winter is the most difficult driving season.
questions.answerB: Checking your vehicle's antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels is especially important during the winter.
questions.answerC: Using cruise control in winter weather is a safe thing to do.
questions.answerD: It is best to use snow tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should not use cruise control on snow, in rain, in fog, or under similar hazardous conditions. Winter is the most difficult driving season and requires extra caution from drivers. It is important to consistently check your antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels. Using snow tires can increase a vehicle's traction on the surface of slippery roads.

questions.question: What do speed limit signs indicate?
questions.answerA: Potential driving speeds for the area
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum speed that is legally allowed to be driven
questions.answerC: The speed drivers should drive in heavy traffic
questions.answerD: The speed drivers should drive under poor conditions
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs indicate the maximum or minimum safe speed that is allowed to be driven on a roadway. The maximum limits are for ideal conditions and you must reduce your speed when conditions require it.

questions.question: Car drivers should know that large trucks:
questions.answerA: Have large blind spots.
questions.answerB: Can stop more quickly than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Do not need more room to maneuver than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: A large truck has large blind spots to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle. Avoid lingering in these areas. Because of their larger size and weight, trucks require more room to maneuver and stop than passenger vehicles.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: School ahead.
questions.answerB: School crossing.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerD: Construction workers on or near the roadway.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that there may be pedestrians crossing the road ahead.

questions.question: On a road which has no sidewalks, a pedestrian should walk on the:
questions.answerA: Side of the road which has the lightest traffic.
questions.answerB: Same side of the road on which traffic is moving.
questions.answerC: Side of the road facing oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Side of the road which has the heaviest traffic.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should walk on the side of the road facing the traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: To prevent hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Ensure that your tires are properly inflated.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed when driving in the rain.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, you should ensure that the tires on your vehicle have good tread depth and are inflated to the proper pressure. Reduce the speed of your vehicle when driving in the rain. Hydroplaning occurs most frequently at higher speeds.

questions.question: You and another vehicle are approaching an intersection that has no traffic signs or signals. Which vehicle has the right-of-way?
questions.answerA: The vehicle on the left
questions.answerB: The vehicle on the right
questions.answerC: The biggest vehicle
questions.answerD: The vehicle that enters the intersection first
questions.explanation: The vehicle on the right has the right-of-way when two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time. When the first driver has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: In which of the following ways can alcoholic beverages affect you?
questions.answerA: It slows your reaction time.
questions.answerB: It gives you a feeling of false confidence.
questions.answerC: It impairs your thinking ability.
questions.explanation: Alcohol dulls the parts of your brain that control inhibition, judgment, and self-control. As a result, you may feel stimulated, lively, and a bit giddy or foolish after consuming alcohol. Alcohol also impairs your reaction time, coordination, and balance. Your vision and ability to judge distance suffers after alcohol consumption, making it difficult to react to your surroundings.

questions.question: When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
questions.answerA: On the main road, just before the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Once you see a toll booth.
questions.answerC: Once you have moved into the exit lane.
questions.answerD: When you first see the exit sign.
questions.explanation: When exiting a highway, you should get into the exit lane well in advance. Do not begin to slow down until after you have moved into the exit lane.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: You may not park:
questions.answerA: On a hill.
questions.answerB: In a parking lot.
questions.answerC: On a crosswalk or in a marked bicycle lane.
questions.answerD: Within 12 inches of the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where it is unlawful to park, including on a crosswalk or in a marked bicycle lane. When parking on the street, you must be within 12 inches of the side of the road.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means that you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with care.
questions.answerB: Continue normally through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed when a green light appears.
questions.answerD: Stop and proceed when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means "caution." If you approach such a light, slow down, look, and proceed with care.

questions.question: You have the right-of-way when turning left on which of the following traffic signals?
questions.answerA: A solid green light
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light
questions.answerC: A green arrow pointing left
questions.explanation: A green steady arrow means you may pass through the intersection in the direction that the arrow is pointing. Oncoming traffic is required to stop for turning traffic.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerA: Entrance to full parking lots.
questions.answerB: Entrance to road construction areas.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Bicycle crossing.
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Fines double in a work zone.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential bicycle cross traffic.

questions.question: When making a turn or lane change, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal immediately before the turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal 100 feet before the turn or lane change, even if no other vehicles are around.
questions.answerC: Signal 100 feet before the turn or lane change, but only when driving in traffic.
questions.explanation: When slowing down, turning, or changing lanes, you should communicate with other drivers. Signal every time you want to change lanes or turn , even if there are no other vehicles in sight.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerA: Changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from a parking area or alley.
questions.explanation: Your turn signals should always be used when you make any movement to the left or right. You should use your signal when pulling into traffic from a curbside parking space, moving into a new lane, or passing another vehicle.

questions.question: A work zone:
questions.answerA: May be moving or stationary.
questions.answerB: Is marked with black and white signs.
questions.answerC: Does not require a driver to slow down and pay extra attention.
questions.explanation: Work zones are often stationary, but they may also be present in the form of moving vehicles striping lines, mowing, or removing snow. Work zones are marked by orange signs with black lettering or symbols. Slow down and pay extra attention when approaching or driving through a work zone.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merging traffic.
questions.answerB: Multiple turns.
questions.answerC: Lane shifting.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: On a freeway, you realize you missed your turn or exit. You should:
questions.answerA: Make the turn quickly from your lane of travel.
questions.answerB: Stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach the next turn, exit, or other location where you can safely turn around.
questions.answerD: Signal other drivers to stop so you can turn.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up, but go on to the next turn or exit where you can safely turn around. It is illegal to back up on a shoulder or a freeway.

questions.question: While driving, your wheels slip off the edge of the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Jerk the steering wheel to force the vehicle back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Speed up and steer back onto the pavement gradually.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes and stop.
questions.answerD: Slow down by gently using the brakes. Turn the steering wheel to return to the pavement at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to leave the road, continue to drive with the wheels off the pavement and reduce your speed by gently applying the brakes. When at a safe speed, turn the steering wheel to return to the pavement. Do not attempt to force your vehicle back onto the pavement by sharply turning the steering wheel.

questions.question: If an oncoming driver is heading toward you in your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn, steer right, and accelerate.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn, steer left, and brake.
questions.answerC: Blow your horn, steer right, and brake.
questions.answerD: Stay in the center of your lane, blow your horn, and brake.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle is approaching you head-on in your lane, you should first honk your horn to attract attention. If the other driver does not move over, try to escape to the right. If you swerve left and the other driver corrects at the last instant, you will still crash. If a collision is unavoidable, brake firmly and steadily. Every mile per hour you slow down will reduce the impact.

questions.question: This sign indicates that:
questions.answerA: There is a steep hill ahead.
questions.answerB: No trucks are allowed on an upcoming hill.
questions.answerC: A logging road is ahead.
questions.answerD: There are trucks on an upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill or downgrade ahead.

questions.question: What is the only way to reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerA: Drink coffee.
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Allow your body time to get rid of the alcohol.
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is to not drink alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: You have been charged with driving under the influence of alcohol and have refused to take the required chemical test. You may lose your driver license for twelve months:
questions.answerA: Only if you are convicted of driving while under the influence of alcohol.
questions.answerB: Only if you are convicted of a traffic violation.
questions.answerC: Because you have refused to take the test.
questions.explanation: Any person operating a motor vehicle in Hawaii consents to having their blood alcohol content (BAC) tested when requested by law enforcement. Refusing to take a chemical test will result in the revocation of your license for a minimum of one year.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: Guide signs are ____ signs that provide directional and mileage information to drivers.
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerB: Red
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Guide signs, sometimes known as destination signs, have a green background and provide directional and mileage information to specific destinations. They can be a helpful resource when driving in unfamiliar locations.

questions.question: When entering a highway from an entrance ramp, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Enter above the speed of traffic to get ahead.
questions.answerB: Enter slowly to avoid other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Stop first, then slowly enter traffic.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of traffic.
questions.explanation: Entrance ramps for highways often have acceleration lanes. When merging with traffic from an acceleration lane, you should put your signal on, look for an opening in traffic, accelerate up to the speed of traffic, and merge into an opening in traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks only.
questions.answerB: Trucks are entering the highway.
questions.answerC: Upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that drivers are approaching a steep hill and should prepare to adjust their speeds to continue to drive safely.

questions.question: Taking drugs along with alcohol:
questions.answerA: Increases the risk of causing a crash.
questions.answerB: Is no more dangerous than consuming alcohol by itself.
questions.answerC: Lessens the effect of alcohol on your ability to drive.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your general driving ability.
questions.explanation: Drugs (including illegal, prescription, and over-the-counter medications) can affect your brain function and impair your ability to drive safely. Combining alcohol with other drugs will increase the risk of a crash.

questions.question: You must yield for emergency vehicles:
questions.answerA: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerB: When you see a flashing red or blue light or hear a siren.
questions.answerC: Only when other vehicles yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren or flashing lights.

questions.question: Your first response to reduced visibility should be:
questions.answerA: Turning on your headlights.
questions.answerB: Reducing your speed.
questions.answerC: Turning on your windshield wipers.
questions.answerD: Looking for road edge markings to guide you.
questions.explanation: Reducing your speed should be your first response to decreased visibility and dangerous road conditions.

questions.question: When merging onto a freeway, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Proceed slowly while waiting for an opening.
questions.answerB: Accelerate to a speed that is faster than the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn on your hazard lights until safely on the freeway.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a freeway, use the on-ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic so you can blend in smoothly and safely. Entering traffic must yield to traffic already on the freeway.

questions.question: A leaky exhaust system in your vehicle is dangerous because it can cause:
questions.answerA: A loss of hearing.
questions.answerB: Pollution.
questions.answerC: Carbon monoxide poisoning.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system carries exhaust gas out of the vehicle and prevents fumes from entering into the passenger compartment. To prevent carbon monoxide poisoning, keep your exhaust system free of leaks. Replace all defective parts immediately.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerB: White
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: Solid white lines are used to separate lanes traveling in the same direction (as well as to mark the right edge of the road). Broken white lines separate lanes traveling in the same direction and may be crossed to pass. Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: You are stopped in a line of vehicles waiting at a stop sign. If there is no cross traffic after the vehicles ahead have passed through the intersection, you:
questions.answerA: May proceed through the intersection without stopping again.
questions.answerB: Must stop again at the stop sign or stop line before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May slowly roll past the stop sign.
questions.answerD: May follow the vehicle directly ahead of you without stopping.
questions.explanation: You must always bring your vehicle to a complete stop and yield to approaching traffic before proceeding past a stop sign. Don't feel pressured by surrounding traffic to avoid making a complete stop.

questions.question: You are driving in moderate traffic on a four-lane highway behind a slow-moving vehicle. Before changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Signal your intentions for at least 100 feet.
questions.answerB: Make sure your blind spot is clear.
questions.answerC: Make sure there is sufficient room in traffic to make the move.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check highway and traffic conditions ahead, to the sides, and to the rear of your vehicle.
